SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name GEORGE HENRY KNOX
Present Address BROADVIEW, S.A.S.K.
Pioneer Address
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1883
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaires.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

RECEIVED
MAY 1 - 1953
SOCIAL LIFE AND VISITING.

No. 9

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTYING, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? [Handwritten: 2 & 3]

How many of these were bachelor's homes? [Handwritten: None, only one in a year.]

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? [Handwritten: After two or three visits a year.]

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? [Handwritten: Other days.]

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? [Handwritten: Mostly without invitation.]

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? [Handwritten: Afternoon.]

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? [Handwritten: Yes, for another.]

But was the invitation to a meal extended when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potatoes" used, or was some other expression common?) [Handwritten: They were just glad of the company and we took anything that was offered.]

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "stopped in"? [Handwritten: Coffee, tea, bread, and butter.]

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? [Handwritten: All went.]

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? [Handwritten: Not many bees in those parts.]

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? [Handwritten: None.]

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. [Handwritten: Yes, in winter.]

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, once a month, etc.? [Handwritten: Just went and visited people and talked lunch along.]
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.) Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within its school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall for town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Has there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
1. Tell what you know of the school. What I know for certain is that there was a school at [location]. If you have not described these on the school, you may do so now.

2. How much of your social life was centered around the school? How much did it involve other activities?

3. Was your first community hall built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

4. How large was it made off? How large was it?

6. To what extent did it take the place of home or the school house as a place for social intercourse and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for dinner parties, gatherings, etc.? If so, why?)

8. How were horses slaughtered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

9. What social games were popular in the early days?

10. Was there any playing for a prize? If so, describe it.

11. Was there any disappointment between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

12. Was playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who favored open, others as an entertainment in the house, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "snark," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? 

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. 

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

How many women belonged? 

How often did it meet? 

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

When was it organized? 

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

14. Describe any other details of childhood, including how you felt about school, family life, friends, and activities.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Insert here what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people from outside the town or village (e.g., within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. mostly the children

people were mostly busy with work.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

for the entire community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

mostly races

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

general lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

cake, pie, sandwiches, meat, tea, lemonade

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

afternoon till after supper, as people had to milk cows

33. Afternoon till after dinner, or until half past six in the evening.
13. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable. bigger as more people attend but not as good a time now as then.
